feed.title: Category: picks | User group for Viennese rubyists

entry.title: Picks / what the vienna.rb team thinks is worth sharing this week
entry.content:
01/06 Picks!

In a series on this website we’ll entertain YOU with our picks - or: what we think is worth sharing - every week. Books, articles, gems, fun stuff… you’re in for an eclectic mix! So, here’s for the one-hundred-fortieth edition:

Laura:
  • The Rubyist’s guide to environment variables - How environment variables really work
  • Bath Ruby - The last batch of Bath Ruby tickets is on sale. Get them while they’re hot! (Also, they might be sold out soon)
  • lesscode - The main ideas behind the less code movement
Markus:
  • Craig Kerstiens’ Top 10 Postgres Features and Tips for 2016
  • Visualizing Algorithms - Not just visualized, but also a discussion of different ways to visualize an algorithm.
  • The Website Obesity Crisis - On the phenomenon of mostly-text websites that keep growing in size each year.

entry.title: Picks / what the vienna.rb team thinks is worth sharing this week
entry.content:
12/30 Picks!

In a series on this website we’ll entertain YOU with our picks - or: what we think is worth sharing - every week. Books, articles, gems, fun stuff… you’re in for an eclectic mix! So, here’s for the one-hundred-thirty-ninth edition:

Laura:
  • How to fix a bug in an Open Source Project - this article isn’t so much about making your first pull request (though it lists a couple of important tips) but rather, about the process of fixing bugs for a codebase you’re unfamiliar with.
  • Ruby 2.3.0 - Ruby 2.3.0 was released on Christmas day.
  • RailsConf CFP - The RailsConf CFP is still open until January 15th.
Markus:
  • Fallout 4 Service Discovery and Relay - You might not care about Fallout 4, but Kyle Kelley’s post on how he figured out how the companion iOS/Android app finds and communicates with the game is a very interesting read in any case.
  • 25,000+ Req/s for Rack JSON API with MRuby - mruby doesn’t get nearly as much coverage as Ruby does, but as Luca Guidi shows, mruby doesn’t have to hide in the shadow of its older sibling, especially when it comes to performance.
  • The 100:10:1 method: my approach to open source - @fogus explains his decision making process for what to release as open source.

entry.title: Picks / what the vienna.rb team thinks is worth sharing this week
entry.content:
12/23 Picks!

In a series on this website we’ll entertain YOU with our picks - or: what we think is worth sharing - every week. Books, articles, gems, fun stuff… you’re in for an eclectic mix! So, here’s for the one-hundred-thirty-eighth edition:

Laura:
  • Junior developer - What does it mean? A look at the responsibilities, rather than the skillset, of a junior developer
  • Shrine - There’s a new file uploader in town! Meet Shrine.
  • 32C3 - Chaos Communication Congress is starting this weekend. Some of the Viennese Rubyists will be there – come say hello! Or if you can’t attend, here is a link to the recordings and live stream.
Markus:
  • The Inescapable Pragmatism of Procedures - Avdi Grimm on the strength and weaknesses of a functional vs. a procedural approach to problems.
  • The Jacob’s Ladder of coding - “Anecdotes and questions about climbing up and down the ladder of abstraction” (plus some interesting tidbits about old computer hardware).
  • Ignorance Beats Empathy - Mike Monteiro on how to achieve better empathy towards users in design.
Ramón:
  • Codecademy’s AngularJS course - I’m about halfway through and have found this helpful and a lot of fun!
  • Christmas Tree Formatter for Rspec - Run your tests festively!
  • RubyMotion motion-support gem - Like ActiveSupport, but for RubyMotion!

entry.title: Picks / what the vienna.rb team thinks is worth sharing this week
entry.content:
12/16 Picks!

In a series on this website we’ll entertain YOU with our picks - or: what we think is worth sharing - every week. Books, articles, gems, fun stuff… you’re in for an eclectic mix! So, here’s for the one-hundred-thirty-seventh edition:

Laura:
  • Italy on Rails - A code-journey through Italy; you can apply by email to participate for two weeks in April/May.
  • Advent of Code - Small and self-contained programming puzzled to count your way to Christmas!
  • Coursera - Coursera now has a Ruby On Rails Specialization from Johns Hopkins University.
Markus:
  • The Adventures of printf: A Short Story - Fred Herbet takes us on a journey of a little guy named printf, who’s in search of mentoring as a programmer — and the greater meaning of why we code.
  • When to not be a software craftsman - Programming is often talked about as either art or a craft. But Chad Fowler argues that sometimes, it’s neither — and that’s ok.
  • I Dreamed of a Perfect Database - Paul Ford thinks about databases, and how we order information can reshape our world.

entry.title: Picks / what the vienna.rb team thinks is worth sharing this week
entry.content:
12/09 Picks!

In a series on this website we’ll entertain YOU with our picks - or: what we think is worth sharing - every week. Books, articles, gems, fun stuff… you’re in for an eclectic mix! So, here’s for the one-hundred-thirty-sixth edition:

Laura:
  • The life-changing magic of tidying up - .. with web components
  • So you want to learn how to code - Isis Anchalee, the person behind the #ILookLikeAnEngineer hashtag, put together a great article with a huge list of resources for people looking to learn how to code, from web development to algorithms.
Markus:
  • To the Moon: Parallels Between Space Missions and Developing Software - Russ Olsen (of Eloquent Ruby and Design Patterns in Ruby fame) presented the keynote at GOTO Berlin 2015. InfoQ interviewed him about it.
  • 7 common database design errors - Demonstrated using real-life examples.
  • The TTY demystified - Did you know that the fancy terminal you’re using for your command line can trace its lineage back to a stock ticker device first released in 1869? And it’s still emulating a video terminal from the 1970s?
